Graphical abstract A facile strategy by etching CeO2 spheres pretreated by different concentrations of H2SO4 or NaOH solution with an ionic liquid (IL) of 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([Bmim][BF4]) was developed to achieve CeO2 nanocubes. CuxO/CeO2 nanocube catalysts were obtained via a deposition−precipitation method for CO-PROX reaction. In this paper, a facile strategy by etching CeO2 spheres pretreated by different concentrations of H2SO4 or NaOH solution with an ionic liquid (IL) of 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([Bmim][BF4]) under hydrothermal condition was developed to achieve CeO2 nanocubes. By depositing CuxO clusters on CeO2 nanocubes via a deposition−precipitation method, CuxO/CeO2 nanocube catalysts loading with different amounts of CuxO clusters were synthesized and the CuxO clusters were highly dispersed onto the surface of CeO2 nanocubes. The Raman spectroscopy, H2-TPR, XPS, and DRIFTS results reveal that there is a strong interaction between CuxO and CeO2. Among these CuxO/CeO2 catalysts, the 10CuCe-2OH-ILs, which was obtained via immersing CeO2 spheres using 2M NaOH, and subsequently being etched by ILs, and then loading ∼10% of copper, exhibits the optimal catalytic performances and stability. The catalytic activity of different catalysts increases in the order of 10CuCe-ILs <10CuCe-1H-ILs <10CuCe-0.1OH-ILs <10CuCe-5OH-ILs <10CuCe-2OH-ILs. The result is in agreement with the order of the surface oxygen vacancy concentration, reducibility and Cu+ content, suggesting that the interaction between CuxO species and surface oxygen vacancies of these CuxO/CeO2 catalysts plays an important role for CO preferential oxidation in H2-rich gases. Keywords CeO2 nanocubes CuxO clusters CO preferential oxidation Surface oxygen vacancy 1 Introduction The proton-exchanged membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) has been considered as one of the most attractive power source from practical and economical points of view for transport, stationary and portable applications, due to its excellent energy efficiency, zero-emission of air pollutants, and low operating temperature [1–4]. However, the trace amounts of CO in hydrogen stream could poison Pt electrode in application for proton exchange membrane fuel cells. The mechanism of CO poisoning of the hydrogen oxidation reaction is that CO chemisorbs on the Pt sites to the exclusion of hydrogen [5]. The reason is that CO is more strongly bonded to platinum than hydrogen, as indicated by a greater potential required for the oxidation of CO than hydrogen, and a sticking probability of CO on platinum of 15 times higher than that of hydrogen on platinum [5]. To date, the water gas shift (WGS) reaction and the CO preferential oxidation (PROX) reaction has been considered to be the most straight forward and effectual method for purifying H2-rich gases to avoid anode poisoning [6–9]. The catalysts with highly active, stable, and selective characteristics are critical factors in the presence of H2 in a wide temperature window (80–250°C) for the CO PROX. Ceria has been widely studied as both catalyst and catalyst support in various areas, such as environment, energy, material, and catalysis, due to its unique properties that include outstanding redox ability and high oxygen storage/release capacity (OSC) between the oxygen vacancies and the Ce4+/Ce3+ redox couple [10–14]. Generally, to enhance ceria catalytic activity for CO PROX, the effective way is to combine ceria with noble metals or other metal oxides to form composite catalysts. In recent studies, ceria has been used as a support for loading various noble metals such as Pt [15], Au [16], Pd [17], Ir [18], and Rh [19] to significantly enhance their catalytic performance for CO PROX reaction. However, the high price and limited resource of noble metals hinder their practical applications to a certain extent. Recently, the studies on CuxO/CeO2 composite catalysts have attracted great attentions for their superior catalytic performance for CO-PROX reaction. As such, CuxO/CeO2 composite catalysts have been proposed as alternatives to replace noble metal-based catalysts because of their excellent catalytic performance, durability, and economy [20–25]. In recent reports, CuxO/CeO2 catalysts have been prepared through different chemical approaches including deposition−precipitation [20], impregnation [26], co-precipitation [27], and sol−gel method [28] for their potential uses in water–gas shift (WGS) reaction [29], soot oxidation [30], and preferential CO oxidation [23]. Wang et al. [20] have synthesized the CuxO/CeO2 catalysts by a deposition−precipitation method and investigated their performance for CO-PROX reaction. It was distinctly confirmed that the highly dispersed CuxO clusters other than the Cu−[Ox]−Ce structure were the crucial active species for CO-PROX reaction. Zheng et al. [21] employed a solvothermal method using ethylene glycol as solvent to synthesize CuO/CeO2 catalysts and they used the CuO/CeO2 catalysts for CO oxidation at low temperature. It was found that the catalyst with CuO loading content at 10wt.% showed the highest catalytic activity. Barbato et al. [31] applied kinetically modeled temperature programmed desorption technique, which is based on the combined experimental and kinetic modeling of the temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 from CuO/CeO2 catalysts, to identify and quantify the active sites of two copper-ceria catalysts with the same copper content prepared by two different methods of solution combustion synthesis and the wet impregnation. Gurbani et al. [32] prepared three CuO-CeO2 catalysts by urea-nitrate combustion (UC), citric acid-based sol–gel (SG) and co-precipitation to study the effect of the preparation method on the redox properties of the catalysts, and to correlate them with the performance of the catalysts for CO oxidation in the presence and absence of hydrogen. They found CuCe-SG and CuCe-UC catalysts show much better performance in CO oxidation, in accordance to their higher redox capacity. From previous investigations, it turns out that a suitable choice of the preparation method obviously affects the strong interaction copper and ceria. Nevertheless, to achieve a high activity for CuO-CeO2 catalysts, temperatures of more than 100°C are usually required, whereas selectivity typically decreases with the temperature because of the undesired oxidation of H2 [33]. The superior catalytic performance may be attributed to the strong interaction of the large amount of well-dispersed CuO species with CeO2, the generation of abundant oxygen vacancies caused by the incorporation of Cu2+ into CeO2 lattice, and the highest concentration of active lattice oxygen. At present, for the mechanism of CO oxidation over CuxO/CeO2 catalysts, the studies showed that both CuO and CeO2 play important roles in the reaction and the reaction occurs at the contact interface of CuO and CeO2 [34]. In this work, we investigated the catalytic performance of highly dispersed CuxO clusters supported on CeO2 nanocubes for the CO-PROX reaction. Various CuxO/CeO2 nanocube catalysts were obtained by treating CeO2 spheres in different concentrations of sulfuric acid or sodium hydroxide and subsequently etching them with an ionc liquid of 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([Bmim][BF4]) followed with the deposition of CuxO clusters on the resulted CeO2 nanocubes via a deposition−precipitation method. The catalyst of 10CuCe-2OH-ILs exhibited the higher catalytic activity for the CO-PROX reaction. This result illustrated that the concentration of the OH• on the surface of CeO2 support influenced the interaction the [Bmim][BF4] with the CeO2 spheres, further affected the interaction between copper and ceria. Simultaneously, we also investigated the influence of the Cu contents for CuxO/CeO2 catalysts on their catalytic performance for CO-PROX reaction. The catalysts of 5CuCe-2OH-ILs and 10CuCe-2OH-ILs have shown the excellent catalytic performance, which could be attributed to the strong interaction between copper and ceria. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis CuxO/CeO2 catalysts were prepared by a deposition−precipitation method. In a typical synthesis, Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (0.98g) was dissolved in deionized water (2.25mL) to obtain a precursor solution, which was then transferred into an ethylene glycol solution (43mL). After magnetically stirring for 30min, the homogenous solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave of 50mL capacity and heated at 140°C for 15h. After the reaction was completed, the reaction vessel was naturally cooled to room temperature and the CeO2 spheres were collected and washed with deionized water and absolute ethanol. Next, the obtained CeO2 spheres were pretreated by immersing in different concentrations of H2SO4 or NaOH solution for 24h. The samples obtained by immersing in 1M H2SO4, 0.1M NaOH, 2M NaOH, and 5M NaOH solution were designated as CeO2-1H, CeO2-0.1OH, CeO2-2OH, CeO2-5OH, respectively. Subsequently, the pretreated CeO2 spheres (100mg) and [Bmim][BF4] ionic liquid (0.5mL) were dispersed in deionized water (20mL) by ultrasonication and vigorous stirring. Then, the suspension was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 150°C for 2h. After being naturally cooled down, the CeO2 nanoparticle assemblies were obtained by centrifugation and washed with distilled water and ethanol several times before being dried at 80°C. For the sequential synthesis of CuxO/CeO2 catalysts via a deposition−precipitation method, the obtained CeO2 nanocubes (0.20g) were suspended in 25mL of deionized water under stirring. Various amount of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O precursor were dissolved in 12.5mL of deionized water and then dropwise added into the above CeO2 suspension. During the process, the pH value of the stock solution was controlled at ca. 9 by adding Na2CO3 aqueous solution (0.50 molL−1). The green precipitates were further aged at room temperature for 1h before centrifugation and then washed by deionized water at room temperature. The product was dried in air at 75°C overnight and then calcined in still air at 400°C ramped with a heating rate of 2°Cmin−1 for 2h. The obtained catalysts were labelled as 10CuCe-1H-ILs, 10CuCe-0.1OH-ILs, 10CuCe-2OH-ILs, 10CuCe-5OH-ILs and 10CuCe-ILs. The CuxO/CeO2 catalysts with different Cu loading content were donated as aCuCe-2OH-ILs (a=2, 5, 10 and 20, a=[Cu/CeO2] wt×100%). 2.2 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was used to characterize the phase structure of the samples. Measurements were performed using a PANalytical Empyrean XRD system operated at a scanning rate of 0.026° with acquisition time of 20ms in a scanning range of 2θ=10−80° using Cu Kα radiation (λ=0. 15,406 Å). Samples for XRD measurements were prepared by gently crushing the obtained products with a mortar and pestle and were placed in a quartz glass holder for characterization. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) characterization was performed on a Tecnai F20 (FEI Company) field emission transmission electron microscope system at an acceleration voltage of 120kV to evaluate the structure, size, morphology and exposed crystal facets of the samples. The samples for TEM measurements were suspended in ethanol and supported onto a holey carbon film on a Cu grid. Surface area measurements were performed on an ASAP 2010 Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) analyzer. XPS measurements were carried out on a XSAM800 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer with an Al Ka (1486.67eV) excitation source to determine the surface compositions and valence states of the catalysts. H2-TPR was performed in a quartz microreactor. Before the analysis, all catalysts were calcined at 400°C in air for 2h. Then about 30mg catalysts were used in each measurement and pretreated with N2 at 100°C for 30min to remove the adsorbed carbonates and hydrates. After cooling down to room temperature and introducing the reduction agent of 5% H2/N2 with a flow rate of 50 mLmin−1, the catalysts were heated up to 500°C from room temperature at a rate of 10°Cmin−1. The diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) experiments were carried out using a Bruker Vertex 70 FT-IR spectrometer equipped with a liquid N2-cooled high-sensitivity MCT detector and a Harrick Praying Mantis DRIFTS cell. The powder catalysts (30mg) were placed in a sample cup inside the DRIFTS cell with CaF2 windows and a heating chamber that allowed samples to be heated. To investigate the process of CO adsorption over copper-ceria catalysts, a “CO adsorption” test was measured. Before the testing, the samples were activated by in situ calcination for 30min in air at 300°C. Subsequently, the system was cooled to a certain temperature (80°C) under pure N2 (30 mLmin−1), and the background spectra were recorded. The feed gas (1% CO+20% O2 in N2) was purged through the catalyst inside the DRIFTS cell (30 mLmin−1), and then the DRIFTS spectra were continuously collected for 30min at 80°C. All DRIFTS data presented here have accordingly been subtracted the background spectrum. Analysis of the spectra has been carried out by using OPUS software. 2.3 Catalytic test The CO-PROX reactivity was tested in a plug-flow reactor by using 50mg of sieved catalyst in a gas mixture of 1% CO/1% O2/50% H2/N2 with a space velocity of 60,000 mLh−1 gcat −1. The gas flow was set as 50mL/min. The CuOx/CeO2 catalysts were deposited on the glass fiber filter substrates in a powder form using a mortar and pestle and packed in the center of a stainless steel (length: 20cm, ID: 5.0mm) to a packing length of 0.6cm. The packed bed reactor volume was approximately 0.12cm3 and length/diameter (L/D) ratio was 1.2. Prior to the measurement, the tested sample was pretreated in oxidative (21%O2/N2) atmospheres at 300°C for 30min before the beginning of activity test experiments as described below. For a typical catalytic run, the copper−ceria sample was heated from 40 to 200°C and was stabilized at each temperature plateau under the same reaction conditions for 40min to reach the equilibrium. The compositions of the effluent gases were measured with an online gas chromatograph (GC 9160 series) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. Two column channels in the GC were used to separate the tested gases. One channel was coupled to a column of Molsieve 5Å to separate CO, O2, and N2, and the other channel was attached a column of PoraPLOT N to isolate CO2. Considering that the total volumes of the reaction gas before and after PROX changed very slightly (<1vol%), the CO conversions and O2 selectivities were calculated according to the following equations: C O c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) : X CO = [ CO ] in − [ CO ] out [ CO ] in × 100 O 2 s e l e c t i v i t y t o C O 2 ( % ) : S O 2 = 1 / 2 ( [ CO ] in − [ CO ] out ) [ O 2 ] in − [ O 2 ] out × 100 where [CO]in and [O2]in are the corresponding GC response peak area values of the inlet gas of CO and O2, respectively, before the reaction, whereas [CO]out and [O2]out are the corresponding GC response peak area values of CO and O2, respectively, after the reaction. 3 Results and discussion The synthetic procedures of CuxO/CeO2 nanocube catalysts involve several steps as illustrated in Scheme 1 . Initially, uniform CeO2 spheres were prepared via a hydrothermal method. Then, the CeO2 spheres were pretreated in different acid or base solution for 24h to investigate the influence of the acid or base solution on the morphology of CeO2 sphere followed with the etching by [Bmim][BF4] to obtain CeO2 nanocubes. Subsequently, CuxO cluster were deposited on CeO2 nanocubes via a deposition−precipitation process to form CuxO/CeO2 nanocubes catalysts. The ILs of 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([Bmim][BF4]) were selected as etching solution to etch CeO2 nanospheres pretreated with different concentrations of NaOH or H2SO4. After depositing CuxO nanoclusters, the CuxO/CeO2 catalysts with different compositions, particle sizes, crystal phases, and surface states can be achieved. The different etching solutions may greatly affect the physic-chemical properties of Ce-Cu catalysts. Firstly, the ILs etching has a great impact on the morphology evolution of the pretreated CeO2 nanospheres in different concentration acid or alkali. Secondly, CeO2 nanospheres pretreated with different concentrations of acid or alkali have different amounts of OH• adsorbed onto the surface of CeO2 sphere. The different reaction degrees between CeO2 nanospheres subsequently treated with different concentrations of acid or alkali and ILs under hydrothermal condition may result in the different surface properties of various CeO2 nanocubes. The OH•-rich surface may lead to the formation of F• ions doped CuxO/CeO2, whereas the CeF3 phase may appear. It can largely affect the catalytic performance of CuxO/CeO2 catalysts. Thirdly, various morphologies and different contents of OH• on the surface of CeO2 nanocubes may remarkably affect the strong interaction between the CuxO clusters and the CeO2 support, resulting in different catalytic performance. The XRD patterns of CeO2 nanocubes obtained by pre-treating under different conditions are shown in Fig. 1 . The XRD profiles of CeO2 nanocubes show similar diffraction peaks that can be attributed to cubic fluorite structure of CeO2 (ICDD 34-0394) (Fig. 1A). After depositing CuxO clusters on the surface of CeO2 nanocubes (Fig. 1B), no typical diffraction peaks belonged to Cu, Cu2O, and CuO species can be observed, which suggests that no crystallized copper species are isolated from the CeO2 surface and the CuxO species are highly dispersed on the surface of CeO2. The CeO2-1H-ILs and CeO2-ILs nanocubes show the additional XRD diffraction peaks assigned to CeF3 phase (ICDD 08-0045) after etching with the ionic liquid of [Bmim][BF4]. The additional crystal phase CeF3 in CeO2-1H-ILs and CeO2-ILs nanocubes may be originated from the excessive reaction between CeO2 and F• ions released from 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([Bmim][BF4]) under hydrothermal condition. Similarly reported in literatures, the surface of CeO2-1H and CeO2 are lack of OH•, and the F• can directly react with CeO2 to form CeF3 without undergoing the exchange between OH• and F•. While, the surface of CeO2 spheres pretreated with concentration NaOH may exist in a large amount of OH•, which can inhibit the direct interaction between F• and CeO2 because the exchange between Ce-OH groups and F• ions can consume a large numbers of F• [35]. The average crystallinte size of CeO2 nanocubes and various CuxO/CeO2 catalysts is estimated by the Scherrer formula and summarized in Table 1 . As it can be seen from XRD in Fig. S1, the position of diffraction peaks of CeO2 shifts to lower 2θ angles after depositing CuxO clusters (Fig. S1), suggesting that the Cu ions may incorporate into ceria lattice and substitute Ce4+ partially [36]. Fig. 2 displays the TEM and HRTEM images of 10CuCe-2OH-ILs catalyst. The results reveal that 10CuCe-2OH-ILs spheres consist of small CeO2 nanocubes with an average diameter of 14.1nm (Fig. 2a and b), which is in agreement with the XRD results. Fig. 2c depicts the HRTEM images of 10CuCe-2OH-ILs, and the interplanar d spacings approximately ∼0.32 and ∼0.27nm corresponding to the {111} and {200} crystal facets of CeO2, respectively, can be clearly discerned. Similar to the XRD results, no separated copper-related (Cu/Cu2O/CuO) phases can be observed in HRTEM, further demonstrating the CuxO species are highly dispersed on the surface of CeO2. Furthermore, the elemental mapping analysis (Fig. 3 ) from the corresponding STEM-EDS data confirm the homogeneous distribution of Cu and Ce in 10CuCe-2OH-Ils catalyst. To observe the morphology and particle size of other CuxO/CeO2 catalysts, the TEM and HRTEM characterizations were carried out and shown in Fig. 4 . It is found that the 10CuCe-1H-Ils catalyst possesses a cubic morphology with an average size of ∼28.9nm as indicated in Fig. 4a and b. The interplanar d spacing of 0.27nm indexed to {100} facets of the fluorite-type CeO2 observed in the HRTEM images shown in Fig. 4c further confirms the presence of CeO2. The cubic CeO2 particles show less aggregation and are almost individually free standing. In comparison, as indicated in Fig. 4d–i, the morphology of 10CuCe-0.1OH-ILs and 10CuCe-5OH-ILs catalysts is in form of nanoparticle assemblies. The nanoparticle assemblies possess a size of 100–150nm and are composed of cubic CeO2 particles with the size of 16.5 and 15.4nm, respectively. The lattice fringes are clearly visible with the d spacings of 0.32, 0.27, and 0.19nm, corresponding to the {111}, {200}, and {220} crystal planes of CeO2, respectively (Fig. 4f and i). However, the 10CuCe-IL is composed of small CeO2 nanoparticles with a diameter of 16.2nm as shown in Fig. S2. It is found that the 10CuxO/CeO2 nanospheres are composed of ultrasmall particle (Fig. S3). From the SEM images of CeO2 nanocubes and CuOx/CeO2 catalysts (Figs. S4 and S5), the morphology of the CeO2 has no variation after depositing the CuOx clusters. Fig. 5 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of CuxO/CeO2 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5A, the 10CuCe-0.1OH-ILs, 10CuCe-2OH-ILs, and 10CuCe-5OH-ILs catalysts exhibit hybrid type II and type IV isotherms, indicating the presence of shaped mesopores that are formed in solids derived from aggregates or agglomerates of particles forming shaped pores [37]. However, the 10CuCe-1H-ILs and 10CuCe-ILs catalysts only show the type II isotherm without mesoporous structures. Simultaneously, it can be observed that all CuxO/CeO2 catalysts appear to be very similar to the isotherms belonging to CeO2 carrier [38]. The BET specific surface area for 10CuCe-1H-ILs catalyst is estimated to be 19.48m2/g and is increased to 47.50m2/g for 10CuCe-5OH-ILs while maintaining the similar pore volume (Table 1). In addition, the pore diameter is similar to each other except for 10CuCe-1H-ILs and 10CuCe-ILs catalysts (Fig. 5B). Thus, the increase of the pore diameter for 10CuCe-0.1OH-ILs, 10CuCe-2OH-ILs, and 10CuCe-5OH-ILs catalysts is attributed to the interparticle porosity. The particle sizes were calculated by BET, XRD, and TEM, respectively, and presented in Table S1. The average particle size calculated by the BET surface area is slightly larger than the average crystallite size determined by Scherrer’s equation and the TEM images and the average crystallite size determined by the Scherrer’s equation is the smallest due the difference of calculation principle. It is in consistent with the results reported in literatures [39]. To investigate the surface compositions and the chemical states of CuxO/CeO2 catalysts, XPS measurements were carried out. The XPS spectras of Ce 3d, Cu 2p, O 1s and F 1s for these CuxO/CeO2 catalysts were displayed in Fig. 6 . The complex spectra of Ce 3d can be resolved into eight components as in Fig. 6A. Two groups of spin-orbital multiplets corresponding to Ce 3d3/2 and Ce 3d5/2 are denoted as u and v, respectively. Previous studies [14,40] indicated that the bands labeled u’ and v’ represent the 3d104f1 initial electronic state corresponding to Ce3+, while the other six bands labeled u”’ and v”’, u” and v”, u and v are related to Ce4+. This suggests that the cerium on the surface of CuxO/CeO2 catalysts exists in two different oxidation states of a large amount of Ce4+ and small amount of Ce3+. The presence of Ce3+ is attributed to the strong interaction between the CeO2 and the surrounding CuOx. This may facilitate the electron transfer process of Ce3+ +Cu2+ ↔ Ce4+ +Cu+ beneficial for achieving high activity in CO oxidation [41]. Furthermore, the ratio of Ce3+ can be estimated from the area of u’ and v’ according to the following equation: C e 3 + ( % ) = S u ′ + S v ′ ∑ ( S u + S v ) × 100 The calculated percentages of Ce3+ for different CuxO/CeO2 catalysts are summarized in Table 2 . It can be seen that the ratio of Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+) increases in the order of 10CuCe-5OH-ILs <10CuCe-0.1OH-ILs <10CuCe-2OH-ILs <10CuCe-1H-ILs <10CuCe-5-ILs. It is may be due to the formation of CeF3 phase over 10CuCe-1H-ILs and 10CuCe-ILs catalysts. It is well-known that the concentration of Ce3+ is directly related to the amount of oxygen vacancies since the oxygen vacancies are formed via the transformation of Ce4+ to Ce3+. For the spectra of Cu 2p shown in Fig. 6B, all CuxO/CeO2 catalysts exhibit the peaks of Cu 2p3/2 at 933.23–935.10eV Cu 2p1/2 at 954.6eV, and the shake-up peak at 939–944eV assigned to Cu2+ and Cu+ at 933.23 and 935.10eV, respectively, indicating the presence of Cu+ species [14]. The existence of Cu+ species is mainly due to the redox equilibrium (Ce3+ + Cu2+ ↔ Ce4+ + Cu+) shifting to the right. In addition, the weak intensity of the shake-up peak has been associated with the presence of CuO in CuxO/CeO2 catalysts [30]. As it can be seen in Table 2, the Cu+/Cu2+ values increase in the order of 10CuCe-0.1OH-ILs <10CuCe-ILs<10CuCe-5OH-ILs <10CuCe-1H-ILs <10CuCe-2OH-ILs. Since the similarity of the ionic radius of Cu+ and Ce4+, the substitution may occur at the interface of two metal oxides and induce the formation of Cu+ and oxygen vacancies [41,42]. The spectrum of O 1s is fitted with three Gaussian peaks, as shown in Fig. 6C. All CuxO/CeO2 catalysts show a main peak at ∼529.7eV attributed to lattice oxygen bonding to CeO2 and CuxO phases, and an additional peak at higher binding energy ∼531.8eV is assigned to the chemisorbed oxygen and oxygen of surface adsorbed water and CO species and the last one at 533.0eV is assigned to the organic oxygen or the presence of Ce3+ surface defects [43]. It can be observed from Table 2 that O″ content of the 10CuCe-2OH-ILs catalyst is higher than other catalysts. The reason may be due to the existence of the amount of OH•. The relative intensity of the third component to the total O 1s peak suggests the presence of the Ce3+ surface defects that are accompanied by the formation of oxygen vacancies [43]. It is also observed that two XPS peaks centered at 684.2–685.0eV and 685.6–686.3eV for F 1s are observed for all CuxO/CeO2 catalysts. The XPS peak located at 684.2–685.0eV is attributed to the fluoride species that are physically adsorbed on the surface of CeO2 [44], while the XPS peak centered at 685.6–686.3eV is ascribed to the substitute F atoms that occupy the oxygen sites in CeO2 crystal lattice [45]. The binding energy of the fluoride species for CeO2 nanoparticle assemblies are shifted to higher energy, which may be due to the doping of F ions into CeO2 lattice. Raman spectroscopy was conducted to afford additional information for the structure of CuxO/CeO2 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 7 , all CuxO/CeO2 catalysts display a main band at ∼458cm−1 associated with the F2g Raman active mode of cubic fluorite structure of CeO2 corresponding to the symmetric breathing mode of oxygen atoms around cerium ions [12,46,47]. This is in agreement with the observations from the XRD results. Compared with pure CeO2 with Raman peak centered at 464cm−1, the F2g band of all CuxO/CeO2 catalysts shifts to lower frequency and is broadened to some extent. This may be due to the fact that the incorporation of Cu in CeO2 lattice may induce the lattice distortion and influence the crystal symmetry, thus resulting in the Raman active mode of CeO2 in CuxO/CeO2 catalysts shifted [43,48]. The broad band at 597cm−1 ascribed to the oxygen vacancies can be clearly observed verifying the presence of the oxygen vacancies induced by incorporating Cu2+ into fluorite CeO2 lattice and the charge balance for the partial replacement of Ce4+ with Cu2+ in the catalysts [49]. According to the literatures [50–52], the area ratio of peaks at 584 and 454cm−1 (denoted as A576/A463) can reflects the concentration of oxygen vacancies in these catalysts, and they deduced that the increasing of the lattice oxygen and oxygen vacancies will be conducive to CO oxidation. The calculated A576/A463 values are also listed in Table 2, which could be observed that the A576/A463 values of 10CuCe-2OH-ILs catalyst is higher than other catalysts, indicating a larger number of oxygen vacancies created in the ceria lattice of these two catalysts, which is in favor of the CO-PROX reaction. To investigate the reducibility and identify different surface oxygen species, H2-TPR characterization was carried out to study CuxO/CeO2 catalysts. The H2-TPR profiles of all CuxO/CeO2 catalysts are displayed in Fig. 8 . The TPR profiles consist of three regions of H2 consumption. The former peak (α) is assigned to the reduction of surface highly dispersed CuxO species strongly interacting with CeO2, i.e., Cu2+ →Cu+ and Cu+ →Cu0; While the second peak (β) should be related to the strong interaction of Cu-[Ox]-Ce structure. The peak γ represents the reduction of bulk CuO interacting weakly with CeO2 to some extent [20,30,53,54]. It can be seen that the reductive peaks over 10CuCe-2OH-IL catalyst all shift to lower temperature, which is in favor for CO-PROX reaction. And the highly dispersed CuxO species and Cu-[Ox]-Ce structure are the active sites for the CO-PROX reaction. To test the potential relationship between the active species and the catalytic behavior during CO-PROX, in situ DRIFTS studies under a reaction system were performed. Fig. 9 shows the DRIFT spectra of CO adsorbed on the 10CuCe-1H-ILs, 10CuCe-2OH-ILs and 10CuCe-ILs catalysts at 130°C. The bands at the 3800–2650cm−1 and 2400–2300cm−1 correspond mainly to hydroxyl species and the CO2 species, which are too weak to observe in the DRIFT spectra of CO adsorbed. The bands below 1750cm−1 are attributed to carbonate and carboxylate. The bands at 2119cm−1 are associated with the CO adsorption at Cu+ sites forming the Cu+-CO species, considering that Cu+-CO species detected on pure Cu2O gives a main IR adsorption band at about 2127cm−1 [50] and the interaction between copper and ceria can make the band shift to the red according to previous contributions [23,55,56]. The content of adsorbed CO are increased and reach the maximum at the 675s with the increasing of the adsorbed time for three samples. Moreover, as reported in literature [23], the intensity of these bands is correlated to the CO oxidation activity of the catalysts and the sequence of the intensity of the bands about Cu+-CO species at 675s is 10CuCe-2OH-ILs >10CuCe-1H-ILs >10CuCe-ILs (Fig. S6). The above results show that CO mainly adsorbed on Cu+ can be readily reduced by CO at 130°C, which is in agreement with the results of H2-TPR experiments. As shown in Fig. 10 , the CO conversion and selectivity toward CO2 for CO-PROX reaction in H2-rich gases (1% CO, 1% O2, 50% H2, and N2 balance) over the CuxO/CeO2 catalysts were tested within the range from 40 to 200°C. No methane is detected in all experiments. From Fig. 10A, it is observed that CO conversion is improved with the increasing of the reaction temperature up to a certain maximum value and then decreased at higher temperature. The 10CuCe-2OH-ILs catalyst presents the highest catalytic activity when the temperature is lower than 150°C. The catalytic activity of different catalysts increases in the order of 10CuCe-ILs <10CuCe-1H-ILs <10CuCe-0.1OH-ILs <10CuCe-5OH-ILs <10CuCe-2OH-ILs, which is consistent with the strength of the interaction between CuxO clusters and CeO2 reflected in Raman spectra, H2-TPR, and XPS analysis. This phenomenon suggests that the interaction between CuxO clusters and CeO2 play an important role in determining the activation of CO oxidation. On the other hand, the selectivity is declined with the increasing of the reaction temperature (Fig. 10B). The drop of selectivity with the increasing of the reaction temperature on CuxO/CeO2 catalysts agrees with the results reported in the literature and is attributed to the fact that the activation energy of H2 oxidation is sensibly higher than that of CO oxidation [57]. The catalytic performance of CuxO/CeO2 catalysts with different Cu loading contents for CO-PROX reaction was investigated as shown in Fig. 11 . It can be seen clearly that the conversion of CO apparently increases with the increasing of Cu content up to 10wt%, and then, decreases sharply for 20CuCe-2OH-ILs catalyst. The conversion of CO is similar for 5CuCe-2OH-ILs and 10CuCe-2OH-ILs catalysts. No additional phase is visible in XRD patterns except for CeO2 phase (Fig. S7). The H2-TPR trace changes slightly as indicated in Fig. S8 and the β peak is broadened for high Cu concentrations. This result confirms the existence of Cu cluster that may contribute to improve the catalytic performance. Meanwhile, the related Raman spectra in Fig. S9 further evidence the absence of separated CuxO structure for CuxO/CeO2 catalysts with Cu loading contents from 2 to 20%. Fig. S10 shows the XPS spectra of Ce, Cu, O, and F elements in different CuxO/CeO2 catalysts of 2CuCe-2OH-ILs, 5CuCe-2OH-ILs, 10CuCe-2OH-ILs, and 20CuCe-2OH-ILs. From the XPS spectra, it can be observed that all catalysts possess two different oxidation states of Ce3+ and Ce4+ on surface of CeO2 and co-exist Cu+ and Cu2+ species for CuxO clusters. And the percentage of Ce3+ is consistent with Ce3+ surface defects reflected in O1s spectra (Table S2). It can be noticed the long-term stability test is studied for 10CuCe-2OH-ILs catalyst (Fig. 12 ) at 100°C, and the CO conversion unchanged after 24h, is close to 87%, indicating that the catalyst has a good stability. Simultaneously, the CO2 selectivity remains approximately constant during this period, which indicates that the rates of the oxidation reactions of both CO and H2 are reduced in the same proportion. From the catalytic performance, it is found that the CuxO/CeO2 catalysts possess different active sites and physicochemical properties that exhibit disparate catalytic abilities for CO-PROX reaction. Strong metal–support interactions (SMSI) has been recently proposed to describe the chemisorption properties of small metal nanoparticles as they are dispersed on the oxide support materials [9,58]. Much evidence suggests that the support can strongly affect the intrinsic activity and selectivity of catalysts, except the same size of metal particles [58–60]. As illustrated in Scheme 2 , the mechanism of CO-PROX reaction over CuxO/CeO2 catalysts is proposed to involve a redox cycle, which commonly takes place at interfaces between CuxO and CeO2 nanocubes [23,43,53]. Initially, CO is adsorbed on surface of CuO species to form Cu+ carbonyl species. Then, the adsorbed CO reacts with the lattice oxygen or the absorbed gaseous oxygen to give rise to CO2 accompanied by the formation of surface oxygen vacancies. Due to the synergism effect, the Cu2+ and Ce4+ are reduced to Cu+ and Ce3+. while the oxygen vacancies are replenished by dissociative dioxide absorbed to regenerate the lattice oxygen sites, leading to the re-oxidation of Cu+ and Ce3+. The existence of the oxygen vacancies on surface of CuxO/CeO2 catalysts plays an important role in CO-PROX reaction since the oxygen vacancies can strongly bind reactants and assist in their dissociation. According to this reaction mechanism, it can be speculated that the highest activity observed for 10CuCe-2OH-IL catalyst may be related to the large amount of highly dispersed active CuxO as proven by H2-TPR analysis and the stronger interaction between CuxO and CeO2 reflected in Raman, H2-TPR, and XPS characterizations. The highly dispersed CuxO cluster provides the active sites for adsorbing CO and promotes the incorporation of Cu2+ into the CeO2 lattice, leading to the formation of Ce3+ and oxygen vacancies. Thus, the interaction between CuxO and CeO2 produces better CO adsorption sites Cu+ to activate the lattice oxygen. 4 Conclusions In this study, a series of catalysts composed of CuxO supported on CeO2 nanocubes were synthesized and their catalytic performance for CO-PROX reaction was investigated. The synthesis was carried out by pretreating CeO2 spheres with H2SO4 or NaOH solution and subsequently etching with [Bmim][BF4] ILs under hydrothermal condition to obtain the CeO2 nanocubes. Then, through a deposition-precipitation process, CuxO/CeO2 catalysts were achieved. Combined with the XPS, Raman, H2-TPR, and in-situ DRIFTS results, it is suggested that the interaction between the highly dispersed CuxO clusters and the CeO2 support plays an important role in the activity process of CO-PROX. Meanwhile, the Cu content also significantly affects for the CuxO/CeO2 catalysts on the CO-PROX reaction. The CO conversion for CO-PROX is similar for 5CuCe-2OH-ILs and 10CuCe-2OH-ILs, while the CO conversion for 2CuCe-2OH-ILs and 20CuCe-2OH-ILs is decreased drastically, demonstrating that the presence of optimal Cu conent over the CuxO/CeO2 catalysts is a vital factor for the CO-PROX reaction. The CuxO/CeO2 catalysts possess superior catalytic conversion, selectivity, and for CO-PROX in H2-rich gases, making them potentially applicable in PEMFC. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, a facile strategy by etching CeO2 spheres pretreated by different concentrations of H2SO4 or NaOH solution with an ionic liquid (IL) of 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([Bmim][BF4]) under hydrothermal condition was developed to achieve CeO2 nanocubes. By depositing CuxO clusters on CeO2 nanocubes via a deposition−precipitation method, CuxO/CeO2 nanocube catalysts loading with different amounts of CuxO clusters were synthesized and the CuxO clusters were highly dispersed onto the surface of CeO2 nanocubes. The Raman spectroscopy, H2-TPR, XPS, and DRIFTS results reveal that there is a strong interaction between CuxO and CeO2. Among these CuxO/CeO2 catalysts, the 10CuCe-2OH-ILs, which was obtained via immersing CeO2 spheres using 2M NaOH, and subsequently being etched by ILs, and then loading ∼10% of copper, exhibits the optimal catalytic performances and stability. The catalytic activity of different catalysts increases in the order of 10CuCe-ILs <10CuCe-1H-ILs <10CuCe-0.1OH-ILs <10CuCe-5OH-ILs <10CuCe-2OH-ILs. The result is in agreement with the order of the surface oxygen vacancy concentration, reducibility and Cu+ content, suggesting that the interaction between CuxO species and surface oxygen vacancies of these CuxO/CeO2 catalysts plays an important role for CO preferential oxidation in H2-rich gases.
coredata.dc:title: Boosting Cu-Ce interaction in CuxO/CeO2 nanocube catalysts for enhanced catalytic performance of preferential oxidation of CO in H2-rich gases
